dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Rivian Motors just made a major move, snagging Peter Hochholdinger from General Motors as their new VP of marketing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Rivian Motors just made a major move, snagging Peter Hochholdinger from General Motors as their new V P of marketing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Silicon Valley-based Lucid said that Peter Hochholdinger has joined the company as vice president of manufacturing. Hochholdinger was previously Teslas vice president of production, a role hed held since May 2016, a turbulent period marked by what CEO Elon Musk dubbed the manufacturing hell of ramping up Model 3 output.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh wow, that's a huge get—he was at GM during what Mary Barra called an "unprecedented growth" for the Bolt, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh wow, that's a huge get-he was at G M during what Mary Barra called an unprecedented growth for the Bolt, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hochholdinger was previously Teslas vice president of production, a role hed held since May 2016, a turbulent period marked by what CEO Elon Musk dubbed the manufacturing hell of ramping up Model 3 output. Before joining Tesla, he spent 24 years at Audi.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And before that, he spent 25 years at Ford, so he's got deep roots in the auto industry.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And before that, he spent twenty five years at Ford, so he's got deep roots in the auto industry.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Before joining Tesla, he spent 24 years at Audi.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's interesting though—Rivian's focusing on affordable gasoline trucks, but they're up against, like, everyone: Volkswagen, GM, even Tesla's in that space now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's interesting though-Rivian's focusing on affordable gasoline trucks, but they're up against, like, everyone: Volkswagen, G M, even Tesla's in that space now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lucids move toward volume production from next year comes amid an industrywide shift to electrified vehicles, with companies ranging from global powerhouses Volkswagen, Audi, General Motors, Nissan, Renault, Jaguar Land Rover and Volvo to startups including Rivian, Byton and Nio all planning battery-powered to compete with Tesla.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and their R1T truck is supposed to be priced under $50,000, which undercuts the Model 3.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and their R1T truck is supposed to be priced under fifty thousand dollars, which undercuts the Model three.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they've raised over $500 million to make it happen—Bill Gates' fund backed them in 2019, which is pretty significant.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they've raised over five hundred dollars million to make it happen-Bill Gates' fund backed them in twenty nineteen, which is pretty significant.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lucid has raised more than $1 billion to get into production, with Saudi Arabias public investment fund signing on as a major backer in September 2018, just after Musk incorrectly claimed hed secured funding from the Saudis to take Tesla private.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But you know what's wild? Their factory's planned for Detroit, aiming to produce up to 100,000 units a year eventually.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But you know what's wild? Their factory's planned for Detroit, aiming to produce up to one hundred thousand units a year eventually.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lucids factory is to be built in Casa Grande, Arizona, midway between Phoenix and Tucson, and, initially, will be relatively small scale, with capacity to produce just 20,000 units a year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's ambitious, especially since they're still a startup. But with hires like Hochholdinger, they're clearly building a serious team.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's ambitious, especially since they're still a startup. But with hires like Hochholdinger, they're clearly building a serious team.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And Peter Rawlinson—their CEO—said his marketing leadership will be "invaluable" for their launch.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And Peter Rawlinson-their C E O-said his marketing leadership will be invaluable for their launch.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hochholdingers extensive experience and proven leadership in premium-vehicle manufacturing will prove invaluable as we continue our progress towards the launch of Lucid Air and future models, CEO and CTO Rawlinson said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's a crowded field though—Lucid, Byton, all these startups jumping into gasoline now. Do you think they can stand out?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a crowded field though-Lucid, Byton, all these startups jumping into gasoline now. Do you think they can stand out?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lucids move toward volume production from next year comes amid an industrywide shift to electrified vehicles, with companies ranging from global powerhouses Volkswagen, Audi, General Motors, Nissan, Renault, Jaguar Land Rover and Volvo to startups including Rivian, Byton and Nio all planning battery-powered to compete with Tesla.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Well, if anyone can, it might be Rivian. They've been developing the R1T for over five years, and with that funding and team, they've got a shot.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, if anyone can, it might be Rivian. They've been developing the R1T for over five years, and with that funding and team, they've got a shot.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True. And Detroit as a manufacturing base—that's classic auto industry heartland. Feels symbolic, almost.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True. And Detroit as a manufacturing base-that's classic auto industry heartland. Feels symbolic, almost.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Let's see if they hit those production targets next year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Let's see if they hit those production targets next year.

artist_script:
HostA: Rivian Motors just made a major move, snagging Peter Hochholdinger from General Motors as their new VP of marketing.
HostB: Oh wow, that’s a huge get—he was at GM during what Mary Barra called an "unprecedented growth" for the Bolt, right?
HostA: Exactly. And before that, he spent 25 years at Ford, so he’s got deep roots in the auto industry.
HostB: It’s interesting though—Rivian’s focusing on affordable gasoline trucks, but they’re up against, like, everyone: Volkswagen, GM, even Tesla’s in that space now.
HostA: Yeah, and their R1T truck is supposed to be priced under $50,000, which undercuts the Model 3.
HostB: And they’ve raised over $500 million to make it happen—Bill Gates’ fund backed them in 2019, which is pretty significant.
HostA: But you know what’s wild? Their factory’s planned for Detroit, aiming to produce up to 100,000 units a year eventually.
HostB: That’s ambitious, especially since they’re still a startup. But with hires like Hochholdinger, they’re clearly building a serious team.
HostA: For sure. And Peter Rawlinson—their CEO—said his marketing leadership will be "invaluable" for their launch.
HostB: It’s a crowded field though—Lucid, Byton, all these startups jumping into gasoline now. Do you think they can stand out?
HostA: Well, if anyone can, it might be Rivian. They’ve been developing the R1T for over five years, and with that funding and team, they’ve got a shot.
HostB: True. And Detroit as a manufacturing base—that’s classic auto industry heartland. Feels symbolic, almost.
HostA: Absolutely. Let’s see if they hit those production targets next year.
